title: 109_hr4153
content: The Act may be cited as the "Medicaid Cash and Counseling Program Act of 2005" and provides an optional choice for self-directed personal assistance services. The Medicaid Cash and Counseling Program Act of 2005 allows states to offer payment for self-directed personal assistance services to individuals who would otherwise require personal care services or home and community-based services. Services cannot be provided to individuals living in a home owned by a service provider. The Medicaid Cash and Counseling Program Act of 2005 allows states to offer self-directed personal assistance services to eligible individuals, ensuring safeguards for health, welfare, and financial accountability. States must provide services to individuals entitled to medical assistance or home and community-based services, who may require self-directed personal assistance. The Medicaid Cash and Counseling Program Act of 2005 allows states to offer self-directed personal assistance services to eligible individuals who may require personal care or home and community-based services. Participants are informed of feasible alternatives under the State's self-directed personal assistance services program. The Medicaid Cash and Counseling Program Act of 2005 allows states to offer self-directed personal assistance services to eligible individuals. Participants are assessed and counseled before enrollment and can manage their budgets. Additional support may be provided upon request. States must report annually on individuals served and expenditures. Evaluations on impact are done every three years. States can provide these services without certain requirements and can limit eligibility and number of persons served. Self-directed personal assistance services allow participants to manage their own budgets and hire individuals to provide personal care services. States can elect to allow participants to choose any capable individual, including relatives, as paid providers. The approved self-directed services plan and budget allow participants to use their budget for items that increase independence or substitute for human assistance, such as a microwave oven or accessibility ramp. This plan must be consistent with specific requirements for self-directed personal assistance services. The participant's representative has control over the budget, planning, and purchase of self-directed personal assistance services, based on an assessment of needs and a person-centered service plan approved by the State. The participant's representative controls the budget, planning, and purchase of self-directed personal assistance services, involving families, friends, and professionals as desired. A budget is developed and approved by the State based on valid cost data, ensuring quality assurance and risk management. Quality assurance and risk management techniques are used in establishing and implementing a self-directed plan and budget. States may use a financial management entity to make payments to providers and track costs. The amendment applies to services provided on or after January 1, 2006.
